test_cases.Title: Verify System Displays First Line Correctly on Application Launch

Steps.Step Description: Launch the application on the supported device.
Steps.Expected Result: Application starts successfully.

Steps.Step Description: Observe the initial screen or landing page after launch.
Steps.Expected Result: The first line is displayed at the top of the screen as specified.

test_cases.Preconditions: Application is installed and configured on the device. User is not logged in (if applicable).
test_cases.Functionality: Display of first line on application launch
test_cases.Dataset: N/A
test_cases.Expected Result: The first line is visible and correctly rendered at the top of the application upon launch.
test_cases.Partial Coverage Description: Covers only the display of the first line on application launch.

test_cases.Title: Verify First Line is Not Displayed When Application Fails to Load

Steps.Step Description: Simulate a scenario where the application fails to load (e.g., disconnect network, corrupt installation).
Steps.Expected Result: Application fails to launch or displays an error message.

Steps.Step Description: Observe whether the first line is displayed in this error state.
Steps.Expected Result: The first line is not displayed when the application fails to load.

test_cases.Preconditions: Application is installed but launch is intentionally disrupted (e.g., network disabled, corrupted files).
test_cases.Functionality: Error handling for first line display
test_cases.Dataset: N/A
test_cases.Expected Result: The first line is not displayed if the application fails to load.
test_cases.Partial Coverage Description: Covers error scenario for first line display.

test_cases.Title: Verify First Line is Displayed Consistently Across Supported Devices

Steps.Step Description: Launch the application on each supported device (e.g., Desktop, Mobile, Tablet).
Steps.Expected Result: Application launches successfully on each device.

Steps.Step Description: Observe the initial screen on each device.
Steps.Expected Result: The first line is displayed at the top of the screen on all devices.

test_cases.Preconditions: Application is installed on all supported devices.
test_cases.Dataset: N/A
test_cases.Expected Result: The first line is consistently displayed at the top of the application across all supported devices.
test_cases.Partial Coverage Description: Covers cross-device consistency for first line display.

test_cases.Title: Verify automatic disconnection after inactivity timeout

Steps.Step Description: Login to the ZENIT Credit Analytics Manager application with valid user credentials.
Steps.Expected Result: User is successfully logged in and lands on the dashboard.

Steps.Step Description: Remain inactive (no mouse, keyboard, or touch input) for the configured inactivity timeout period (e.g., 15 minutes).
Steps.Expected Result: No activity is detected by the system during the timeout period.

Steps.Step Description: Observe the application after the inactivity timeout elapses.
Steps.Expected Result: User is automatically logged out and redirected to the login page with a message indicating disconnection due to inactivity.

test_cases.Preconditions: User account exists and is active. Inactivity timeout is configured (e.g., 15 minutes). User is logged in.
test_cases.Functionality: Session timeout and automatic logout for inactivity
test_cases.Dataset: Valid user credentials; inactivity timeout value (e.g., 15 minutes)
test_cases.Expected Result: User is automatically logged out after the inactivity timeout and receives an appropriate message.

test_cases.Title: Verify session persistence with user activity before timeout

Steps.Step Description: Login to the ZENIT Credit Analytics Manager application with valid user credentials.
Steps.Expected Result: User is successfully logged in and lands on the dashboard.

Steps.Step Description: Perform any user activity (e.g., click a menu item, type in a field) before the inactivity timeout period elapses (e.g., at 10 minutes if timeout is 15 minutes).
Steps.Expected Result: System registers the user activity and resets the inactivity timer.

Steps.Step Description: Continue to perform periodic activity before each timeout period elapses for a total duration exceeding the configured timeout (e.g., 30 minutes).
Steps.Expected Result: User remains logged in and is not disconnected due to inactivity.

test_cases.Preconditions: User account exists and is active. Inactivity timeout is configured. User is logged in.
test_cases.Functionality: Session timeout reset on user activity
test_cases.Dataset: Valid user credentials; inactivity timeout value (e.g., 15 minutes)
test_cases.Expected Result: User remains logged in as long as activity occurs before the inactivity timeout.

test_cases.Title: Verify warning message before automatic disconnection (if applicable)

Steps.Step Description: Login to the ZENIT Credit Analytics Manager application with valid user credentials.
Steps.Expected Result: User is successfully logged in and lands on the dashboard.

Steps.Step Description: Remain inactive for a period just before the inactivity timeout threshold (e.g., 1 minute before timeout).
Steps.Expected Result: No activity is detected by the system.

Steps.Step Description: Observe if a warning message or popup is displayed indicating imminent disconnection due to inactivity.
Steps.Expected Result: A warning message is displayed to the user indicating that the session will expire soon due to inactivity.

Steps.Step Description: Remain inactive until the timeout elapses.
Steps.Expected Result: User is automatically logged out and redirected to the login page.

test_cases.Preconditions: User account exists and is active. Inactivity timeout and warning threshold are configured. User is logged in.
test_cases.Dataset: Valid user credentials; inactivity timeout and warning threshold values
test_cases.Expected Result: User receives a warning before being logged out due to inactivity, then is logged out if no action is taken.
test_cases.Partial Coverage Description: Assumes system provides a warning before logout; skip if not applicable.

test_cases.Title: Verify session termination on multiple devices after inactivity

Steps.Step Description: Login to the ZENIT Credit Analytics Manager application on two different devices or browsers using the same user account.
Steps.Expected Result: User is successfully logged in on both devices/browsers.

Steps.Step Description: Remain inactive on both devices for the configured inactivity timeout period.
Steps.Expected Result: No activity is detected on either device/browser.

Steps.Step Description: Observe both devices after the inactivity timeout elapses.
Steps.Expected Result: User is automatically logged out from both sessions and redirected to the login page on both devices.

test_cases.Preconditions: User account exists and is active. Inactivity timeout is configured. User is logged in on multiple devices/browsers.
test_cases.Functionality: Session timeout enforcement across multiple sessions/devices
test_cases.Dataset: Valid user credentials; two devices or browsers; inactivity timeout value
test_cases.Expected Result: User is logged out from all inactive sessions after the timeout period.
test_cases.Partial Coverage Description: Assumes session management is shared across devices; adjust if sessions are independent.

test_cases.Title: Verify user can log in again immediately after automatic disconnection

Steps.Step Description: Login to the ZENIT Credit Analytics Manager application with valid user credentials.
Steps.Expected Result: User is successfully logged in and lands on the dashboard.

Steps.Step Description: Remain inactive until automatic disconnection occurs due to inactivity timeout.
Steps.Expected Result: User is logged out and redirected to the login page.

Steps.Step Description: Attempt to log in again immediately with the same credentials.
Steps.Expected Result: User is able to log in successfully without errors or lockout.

test_cases.Preconditions: User account exists and is active. Inactivity timeout is configured. User is logged in.
test_cases.Dataset: Valid user credentials; inactivity timeout value
test_cases.Expected Result: User can log in again immediately after being logged out for inactivity.

test_cases.Title: Verify Document Introduction Section Presence and Content

Steps.Step Description: Open the functional specification document.
Steps.Expected Result: The document opens successfully without errors.

Steps.Step Description: Navigate to the beginning of the document.
Steps.Expected Result: The introduction section is located at the start of the document.

Steps.Step Description: Read the content of the introduction section.
Steps.Expected Result: The introduction clearly states that the purpose of the document is to translate user requirements into functional specifications.

test_cases.Preconditions: Functional specification document is available and accessible to the tester.
test_cases.Dataset: Functional specification document (latest version)
test_cases.Expected Result: The introduction section is present at the beginning of the document and accurately describes its purpose as translating user requirements into functional specifications.
test_cases.Partial Coverage Description: Covers only the presence and correctness of the introduction section.

test_cases.Title: Verify Absence of Introduction Section in Functional Specification Document

Steps.Step Description: Open the functional specification document.
Steps.Expected Result: The document opens successfully without errors.

Steps.Step Description: Navigate to the beginning of the document.
Steps.Expected Result: The introduction section is not present at the start of the document.

test_cases.Preconditions: Functional specification document is available and accessible to the tester.
test_cases.Dataset: Functional specification document (latest version)
test_cases.Expected Result: The introduction section is missing from the document, which is a defect to be reported.
test_cases.Partial Coverage Description: Covers the negative scenario of missing introduction section.

test_cases.Title: Verify Introduction Section Content Matches User Requirements Translation Purpose

Steps.Step Description: Open the functional specification document.
Steps.Expected Result: The document opens successfully without errors.

Steps.Step Description: Navigate to the introduction section.
Steps.Expected Result: The introduction section is present.

Steps.Step Description: Compare the content of the introduction section with the expected purpose: 'translating into functional specifications what is expressed in the user requirements document.'
Steps.Expected Result: The introduction section content matches the expected purpose without deviation or ambiguity.

test_cases.Preconditions: Functional specification document is available and accessible to the tester. Expected introduction content is defined.
test_cases.Dataset: Functional specification document (latest version), expected introduction text
test_cases.Expected Result: The introduction section content exactly matches the defined purpose of translating user requirements into functional specifications.
test_cases.Partial Coverage Description: Covers content accuracy of the introduction section.

test_cases.Title: Verify Correct Display and Description of Abbreviations in Glossary

Steps.Step Description: Navigate to the glossary or abbreviation section of the application.
Steps.Expected Result: Glossary/abbreviation section is displayed.

Steps.Step Description: Review the list of terms and their corresponding descriptions.
Steps.Expected Result: All terms and their descriptions are visible and readable.

Steps.Step Description: Verify that each abbreviation (e.g., ADI, ADM, AWP, etc.) matches its correct description as per the requirements.
Steps.Expected Result: Each abbreviation is accurately described according to the provided specification.

test_cases.Preconditions: User has access to the application and is authenticated if required.
test_cases.Dataset: List of abbreviations and descriptions as per requirement.
test_cases.Expected Result: All abbreviations are displayed with their correct and complete descriptions as specified.

test_cases.Title: Verify Handling of Unknown or Undefined Abbreviations

Steps.Step Description: Navigate to the glossary or abbreviation section of the application.
Steps.Expected Result: Glossary/abbreviation section is displayed.

Steps.Step Description: Search for an abbreviation not present in the provided list (e.g., 'XYZ').
Steps.Expected Result: System processes the search request.

Steps.Step Description: Observe the system's response to the unknown abbreviation.
Steps.Expected Result: System displays a clear message indicating the abbreviation is not found or is undefined.

test_cases.Preconditions: User has access to the application and is authenticated if required.
test_cases.Dataset: Abbreviation not present in the list (e.g., 'XYZ').
test_cases.Expected Result: System provides a user-friendly message for unknown or undefined abbreviations.

test_cases.Title: Verify Alphabetical Ordering of Abbreviations in Glossary

Steps.Step Description: Navigate to the glossary or abbreviation section of the application.
Steps.Expected Result: Glossary/abbreviation section is displayed.

Steps.Step Description: Review the order of the abbreviations listed.
Steps.Expected Result: Abbreviations are listed in alphabetical order.

test_cases.Preconditions: User has access to the application and is authenticated if required.
test_cases.Dataset: Full list of abbreviations as per requirement.
test_cases.Expected Result: Abbreviations are displayed in alphabetical order for ease of reference.

test_cases.Title: Verify Accessibility of Glossary/Abbreviation Section

Steps.Step Description: Attempt to access the glossary/abbreviation section from the main navigation or help menu.
Steps.Expected Result: Glossary/abbreviation section is accessible from the main navigation or help menu.

test_cases.Preconditions: User has access to the application and is authenticated if required.
test_cases.Dataset: N/A
test_cases.Expected Result: Glossary/abbreviation section is easily accessible from the main navigation or help menu.

test_cases.Title: Verify Consistency of Abbreviation Usage Across Application

Steps.Step Description: Identify a sample abbreviation (e.g., 'AWP') from the glossary.
Steps.Expected Result: Sample abbreviation is identified.

Steps.Step Description: Navigate to various sections of the application where the abbreviation is used (e.g., reports, forms, help pages).
Steps.Expected Result: Abbreviation is found in multiple sections.

Steps.Step Description: Verify that the abbreviation is used consistently and matches the definition provided in the glossary.
Steps.Expected Result: Abbreviation usage is consistent and matches the glossary definition in all sections.

test_cases.Preconditions: User has access to the application and is authenticated if required.
test_cases.Dataset: Sample abbreviations from the glossary (e.g., 'AWP', 'VLT').
test_cases.Expected Result: Abbreviations are used consistently and correctly throughout the application.

test_cases.Title: Verify Comprehensive Visibility of Customer Credit Status with Drill-Down

Steps.Step Description: Login to the ZENIT back office as a Finance user.
Steps.Expected Result: User is successfully authenticated and redirected to the dashboard.

Steps.Step Description: Navigate to the 'Customer Credit Status' section.
Steps.Expected Result: The section displays a list of all retail customers with their current credit status.

Steps.Step Description: Select a specific customer from the list.
Steps.Expected Result: Detailed credit information for the selected customer is displayed, including breakdown by business area.

Steps.Step Description: Drill down into a specific business area for the selected customer.
Steps.Expected Result: A detailed view of credit status for the chosen business area is presented, showing all relevant transactions and limits.

test_cases.Preconditions: User has valid Finance credentials. Customer and business area data are available in the system.
test_cases.Dataset: Finance user credentials; at least one customer with multiple business areas and credit data.
test_cases.Expected Result: The system provides comprehensive visibility of the customer's credit status, allowing drill-down into all business areas without errors or missing data.

test_cases.Title: Verify Real-Time Dashboard Displays Centralized Credit Information

Steps.Step Description: Login to the ZENIT back office as a Credit team member.
Steps.Expected Result: User is authenticated and dashboard is displayed.

Steps.Step Description: Observe the real-time dashboard for credit management.
Steps.Expected Result: Dashboard displays up-to-date, centralized credit information for all points of sale.

Steps.Step Description: Trigger a credit status update for a point of sale (simulate transaction or credit change).
Steps.Expected Result: Dashboard updates in real-time to reflect the new credit status.

test_cases.Preconditions: User has valid Credit team credentials. System is connected to live data feeds.
test_cases.Dataset: Credit team user credentials; at least one point of sale with credit data; ability to simulate credit status change.
test_cases.Expected Result: The dashboard provides centralized, real-time visibility and control of credit information for all points of sale.

test_cases.Title: Verify Category Assignment Based on Cluster PV (Canale RG on MDM)

Steps.Step Description: Access the ZENIT back office as an admin user.
Steps.Expected Result: Admin user is authenticated and main interface is displayed.

Steps.Step Description: Navigate to the 'Points of Sale' management section.
Steps.Expected Result: List of all points of sale is displayed with their details.

Steps.Step Description: Select or create a point of sale with Cluster PV set to 'PGI'.
Steps.Expected Result: Point of sale details are shown with Cluster PV as 'PGI'.

Steps.Step Description: Verify the value of 'Canale 1' for the selected point of sale.
Steps.Expected Result: 'Canale 1' is automatically set to 'BRANDED'.

Steps.Step Description: Repeat steps 3-4 for each Cluster PV value: PGS, Negozio, Wincity, Pos AWP Only, Pos GNTN e AWP, Pos GNTN Only, Gaming Hall.
Steps.Expected Result: 'Canale 1' is set to 'BRANDED' for PGS, Negozio, Wincity; 'UNBRANDED' for Pos AWP Only, Pos GNTN e AWP, Pos GNTN Only, Gaming Hall.

test_cases.Preconditions: Admin user credentials. Points of sale with all relevant Cluster PV values exist or can be created.
test_cases.Dataset: Admin credentials; Cluster PV values: PGI, PGS, Negozio, Wincity, Pos AWP Only, Pos GNTN e AWP, Pos GNTN Only, Gaming Hall.
test_cases.Expected Result: The system assigns 'Canale 1' correctly based on the Cluster PV value according to the specified mapping.

test_cases.Title: Verify Display and Aggregation of Credit Lines per Platform (SIMP and GEO)

Steps.Step Description: Login to the ZENIT back office as a Finance user.
Steps.Expected Result: User is authenticated and dashboard is displayed.

Steps.Step Description: Navigate to the 'Credit Lines' section.
Steps.Expected Result: Credit lines for all points of sale are displayed, grouped by platform (SIMP and GEO).

Steps.Step Description: Select a point of sale and view its credit lines.
Steps.Expected Result: All relevant credit lines for the selected point of sale are displayed, with correct association to SIMP or GEO.

Steps.Step Description: Verify that SIMP credit lines include: Totocalcio, Horse Racing, Fixed Odds Sports, Virtual Race, Global Game.
Steps.Expected Result: SIMP credit lines are correctly listed.

Steps.Step Description: Verify that GEO credit lines include: Numerical Games (GNTN), Corner (PGI and PGS), Game Accounts (Servizi - CONTI GIOCO).
Steps.Expected Result: GEO credit lines are correctly listed.

test_cases.Preconditions: Finance user credentials. Points of sale with credit lines on both SIMP and GEO platforms exist.
test_cases.Dataset: Finance user credentials; points of sale with credit lines on SIMP and GEO.
test_cases.Expected Result: The system displays and aggregates credit lines per platform accurately for each point of sale.

test_cases.Title: Verify Weekly Management of Credit Lines

Steps.Step Description: Login to the ZENIT back office as a Finance user.
Steps.Expected Result: User is authenticated and dashboard is displayed.

Steps.Step Description: Navigate to the 'Credit Lines Management' section.
Steps.Expected Result: Section displays all credit lines and their management frequency.

Steps.Step Description: Select a credit line (e.g., Totocalcio) and view its management details.
Steps.Expected Result: Credit line details indicate that management is performed on a weekly basis.

Steps.Step Description: Repeat for other credit lines (SIMP and GEO).
Steps.Expected Result: All credit lines show weekly management frequency.

test_cases.Preconditions: Finance user credentials. Credit lines are configured in the system.
test_cases.Dataset: Finance user credentials; credit lines on SIMP and GEO.
test_cases.Expected Result: All credit lines are managed on a weekly basis as indicated in the system.

test_cases.Title: Verify Access Control for Finance and Credit Team Roles

Steps.Step Description: Attempt to login to ZENIT back office as a user with Finance role.
Steps.Expected Result: User is authenticated and has access to all credit management features.

Steps.Step Description: Attempt to login as a user with Credit team role.
Steps.Expected Result: User is authenticated and has access to dashboard and decision-making tools.

Steps.Step Description: Attempt to login as a user with no assigned role.
Steps.Expected Result: User is denied access to credit management features.

test_cases.Preconditions: Users with Finance, Credit team, and no roles exist in the system.
test_cases.Dataset: Credentials for Finance, Credit team, and unassigned users.
test_cases.Expected Result: Only authorized roles (Finance, Credit team) can access relevant features; unauthorized users are denied access.

test_cases.Title: Verify Multibrand Integration for Transaction Validation

Steps.Step Description: Login to ZENIT as a Finance user.
Steps.Expected Result: User is authenticated and dashboard is displayed.

Steps.Step Description: Initiate a transaction from a multibrand business platform (e.g., SNAI) integrated with ZENIT.
Steps.Expected Result: Transaction request is sent to ZENIT's central module.

Steps.Step Description: Verify that ZENIT performs credit limit verification and updates credit movement accordingly.
Steps.Expected Result: Transaction is validated or rejected based on credit limit; credit movement is updated in ZENIT.

test_cases.Preconditions: ZENIT is integrated with at least one multibrand platform (e.g., SNAI). Credit limits are configured.
test_cases.Dataset: Finance user credentials; multibrand platform with transaction capability; configured credit limits.
test_cases.Expected Result: ZENIT correctly validates transactions from multibrand platforms and updates credit movements as per business rules.

test_cases.Title: Verify Integration with MDM via ESB for PoS Master Data

Steps.Step Description: Trigger a request in ZENIT to retrieve PoS master data via ESB from MDM.
Steps.Expected Result: ZENIT sends a request to ESB for PoS master data.

Steps.Step Description: Monitor the ESB for the response from MDM containing PoS master data.
Steps.Expected Result: ESB returns the correct PoS master data as managed in MDM/CRM.

Steps.Step Description: Validate that ZENIT correctly receives and stores the PoS master data.
Steps.Expected Result: ZENIT stores and displays the PoS master data accurately for all countries.

test_cases.Preconditions: MDM/CRM contains valid PoS master data for all countries. ESB is operational. ZENIT is configured for integration.
test_cases.Functionality: PoS master data retrieval and propagation
test_cases.Dataset: Sample PoS master data in MDM/CRM for multiple countries.
test_cases.Expected Result: ZENIT successfully retrieves and stores PoS master data from MDM via ESB for all countries.

test_cases.Title: Verify Integration with MST for Horse Race Terminal Credit Availability

Steps.Step Description: Request credit availability information for Horse Race terminals from MST via ZENIT.

test_cases.Title: Automatic Logout After Inactivity Timeout

Steps.Step Description: Log in to the application with valid user credentials.
Steps.Expected Result: User is successfully logged in and navigated to the main dashboard.

Steps.Step Description: Remain inactive (do not interact with the application) for the configured inactivity timeout period (e.g., 15 minutes).
Steps.Expected Result: No user activity is detected during the timeout period.

Steps.Step Description: Observe the application after the inactivity timeout has elapsed.
Steps.Expected Result: The system automatically logs out the user and redirects to the login page or displays a session expired message.

test_cases.Preconditions: User account exists. Inactivity timeout is configured (e.g., 15 minutes). User is logged in.
test_cases.Dataset: Valid user credentials; inactivity timeout value (e.g., 15 minutes)
test_cases.Expected Result: User is automatically logged out after the inactivity timeout period with no activity detected.

test_cases.Title: Session Remains Active with User Activity

Steps.Step Description: Log in to the application with valid user credentials.
Steps.Expected Result: User is successfully logged in and navigated to the main dashboard.

Steps.Step Description: Perform any user activity (e.g., click a button, navigate to another page) before the inactivity timeout period elapses.
Steps.Expected Result: User activity is registered by the system.

Steps.Step Description: Continue to interact with the application periodically, ensuring no period of inactivity exceeds the timeout value.
Steps.Expected Result: Session remains active and user is not logged out.

test_cases.Preconditions: User account exists. Inactivity timeout is configured. User is logged in.
test_cases.Dataset: Valid user credentials; inactivity timeout value (e.g., 15 minutes)
test_cases.Expected Result: User session remains active as long as user activity occurs within the timeout period.

test_cases.Title: Warning Message Before Automatic Logout Due to Inactivity

Steps.Step Description: Log in to the application with valid user credentials.
Steps.Expected Result: User is successfully logged in and navigated to the main dashboard.

Steps.Step Description: Remain inactive for a period just before the inactivity timeout threshold (e.g., 1 minute before timeout).
Steps.Expected Result: No user activity is detected during this period.

Steps.Step Description: Observe if a warning message or prompt appears indicating impending logout due to inactivity.
Steps.Expected Result: A warning message is displayed to the user, indicating that the session will expire soon due to inactivity.

test_cases.Preconditions: User account exists. Inactivity timeout and warning period are configured. User is logged in.
test_cases.Dataset: Valid user credentials; inactivity timeout value (e.g., 15 minutes); warning period (e.g., 1 minute before timeout)
test_cases.Expected Result: User receives a warning message before being automatically logged out due to inactivity.
test_cases.Partial Coverage Description: Covers warning notification aspect if implemented.

test_cases.Title: Session Termination on Multiple Devices After Inactivity

Steps.Step Description: Log in to the application on two different devices using the same user account.
Steps.Expected Result: User is successfully logged in on both devices.

Steps.Step Description: Remain inactive on both devices for the configured inactivity timeout period.
Steps.Expected Result: No user activity is detected on either device during the timeout period.

Steps.Step Description: Observe the session status on both devices after the timeout period elapses.
Steps.Expected Result: The system automatically logs out the user on both devices after the inactivity timeout.

test_cases.Preconditions: User account exists. Inactivity timeout is configured. User is logged in on multiple devices.
test_cases.Dataset: Valid user credentials; two devices (e.g., desktop and laptop); inactivity timeout value
test_cases.Expected Result: User is logged out from all devices after inactivity timeout is reached on each device.
test_cases.Partial Coverage Description: Covers multi-device session management.

test_cases.Title: Session Persists When Application is Minimized or in Background

Steps.Step Description: Log in to the application with valid user credentials.
Steps.Expected Result: User is successfully logged in and navigated to the main dashboard.

Steps.Step Description: Minimize the application window or move it to the background without interacting with it for the inactivity timeout period.
Steps.Expected Result: No user activity is detected during this period.

Steps.Step Description: Restore the application window after the timeout period has elapsed.
Steps.Expected Result: The system automatically logs out the user and prompts for login again, or displays a session expired message.

test_cases.Preconditions: User account exists. Inactivity timeout is configured. User is logged in.
test_cases.Dataset: Valid user credentials; inactivity timeout value
test_cases.Expected Result: User is logged out after inactivity even if the application is minimized or in the background.
test_cases.Partial Coverage Description: Covers inactivity detection when application is not in focus.

test_cases.Title: No Logout Triggered for Background System Processes

Steps.Step Description: Log in to the application with valid user credentials.
Steps.Expected Result: User is successfully logged in and navigated to the main dashboard.

Steps.Step Description: Allow background system processes (e.g., notifications, background data sync) to occur without user interaction for the inactivity timeout period.
Steps.Expected Result: No user activity is detected, only background processes are running.

Steps.Step Description: Observe the session status after the inactivity timeout period has elapsed.
Steps.Expected Result: The system automatically logs out the user, as background processes do not count as user activity.

test_cases.Preconditions: User account exists. Inactivity timeout is configured. User is logged in. Background processes are enabled.
test_cases.Dataset: Valid user credentials; inactivity timeout value; background process enabled
test_cases.Expected Result: User is logged out after inactivity timeout even if background processes are running.

test_cases.Title: Session Timeout Value Configuration Verification

Steps.Expected Result: User is successfully logged in and navigated to the main dashboard.

Steps.Step Description: Verify the current inactivity timeout value in the system configuration.
Steps.Expected Result: Inactivity timeout value is as per security policy (e.g., 15 minutes).

Steps.Step Description: Remain inactive for a period less than the configured timeout value.
Steps.Expected Result: User remains logged in.

Steps.Step Description: Remain inactive for a period exceeding the configured timeout value.
Steps.Expected Result: User is automatically logged out after the timeout period.

test_cases.Preconditions: User account exists. Inactivity timeout is configurable. User is logged in.
test_cases.Dataset: Valid user credentials; system configuration access; inactivity timeout value
test_cases.Expected Result: System enforces the configured inactivity timeout value for automatic logout.
test_cases.Partial Coverage Description: Covers configuration and enforcement of timeout value.

Steps.Step Description: Verify that the login record contains user ID, login timestamp, and user role.
Steps.Expected Result: All required details (user, login time, role) are present in the record.

test_cases.Functionality: Access control for login tracking data

test_cases.Title: Verify Login Tracking Data Integrity and Immutability (SOX Compliance)

Steps.Step Description: Log in to the system as a Control Room user.
Steps.Expected Result: User is successfully logged in.

Steps.Step Description: Access the login tracking module.
Steps.Expected Result: Login tracking module is accessible.

Steps.Step Description: Attempt to modify or delete an existing login activity record.
Steps.Expected Result: System prevents modification or deletion of login activity records.

test_cases.Preconditions: Control Room user account exists. System is operational. Login activities exist in the system.

test_cases.Expected Result: Login tracking data cannot be modified or deleted, ensuring audit log integrity.

test_cases.Title: Verify Log Generation for SOX-Relevant Actions

Steps.Step Description: Log in to the application as a user with permissions to perform SOX-relevant actions (e.g., create, update, delete financial records).
Steps.Expected Result: User is successfully logged in.

Steps.Step Description: Perform a SOX-relevant action, such as creating a new financial record.
Steps.Expected Result: Action is completed successfully in the application.

Steps.Step Description: Access the application log storage or monitoring system.
Steps.Expected Result: A log entry corresponding to the performed action is present.

Steps.Step Description: Verify that the log entry contains required details: user ID, timestamp, action performed, affected record, and outcome.
Steps.Expected Result: Log entry contains all required SOX-compliant fields.

test_cases.Preconditions: User account with appropriate permissions exists. Log storage is accessible. SOX-relevant actions are enabled in the environment.
test_cases.Functionality: SOX-compliant log traceability for critical actions
test_cases.Dataset: User credentials, sample financial record data
test_cases.Expected Result: All SOX-relevant actions are logged with complete, traceable, and compliant information.

test_cases.Title: Verify Log Integrity and Tamper Detection

Steps.Step Description: Perform a SOX-relevant action in the application (e.g., update a financial record).
Steps.Expected Result: Action is completed and logged.

Steps.Step Description: Attempt to modify or delete the corresponding log entry directly in the log storage (if possible, simulate unauthorized access).
Steps.Expected Result: System prevents modification or deletion of the log entry, or logs the tampering attempt.

Steps.Step Description: Review the log storage for evidence of tampering or unauthorized access attempts.
Steps.Expected Result: Any tampering attempt is either blocked or recorded as a separate log entry.

test_cases.Preconditions: Log storage is accessible. User with SOX-relevant permissions is available. Ability to simulate unauthorized access (test or staging environment).
test_cases.Functionality: Log integrity and tamper detection for SOX compliance
test_cases.Dataset: User credentials, access to log storage
test_cases.Expected Result: Log entries cannot be altered or deleted without detection; tampering attempts are logged or blocked.

test_cases.Title: Verify Log Retention Policy for SOX Compliance

Steps.Step Description: Perform a SOX-relevant action and confirm it is logged.
Steps.Expected Result: Action is logged with all required details.

Steps.Step Description: Check the log storage for retention settings (e.g., logs must be retained for at least 7 years as per SOX).
Steps.Expected Result: Retention policy is configured as per SOX requirements.

Steps.Step Description: Attempt to delete a log entry before the retention period expires (if possible, simulate via admin interface or direct access).
Steps.Expected Result: System prevents deletion of log entries before the retention period ends.

test_cases.Preconditions: Log storage is accessible. Retention policy is configurable. User with admin access is available.
test_cases.Functionality: Log retention enforcement for SOX compliance
test_cases.Dataset: User credentials, admin access
test_cases.Expected Result: Logs are retained for the required period and cannot be deleted prematurely.

test_cases.Title: Verify Log Access Control and Audit Trail

Steps.Step Description: Attempt to access application logs as a regular user without log access permissions.
Steps.Expected Result: Access to logs is denied.

Steps.Step Description: Access logs as an authorized admin user.
Steps.Expected Result: Admin user is able to view logs.

Steps.Step Description: Review the audit trail for log access events.
Steps.Expected Result: All log access events are recorded, including user ID, timestamp, and accessed log details.

test_cases.Preconditions: User accounts with and without log access permissions exist. Audit trail functionality is enabled.
test_cases.Functionality: Log access control and audit trail for SOX compliance
test_cases.Dataset: User credentials (regular and admin)
test_cases.Expected Result: Only authorized users can access logs; all access is auditable and traceable.

test_cases.Title: Verify Log Format and Required Fields for SOX Compliance

Steps.Step Description: Perform a SOX-relevant action in the application.
Steps.Expected Result: Action is completed and logged.

Steps.Step Description: Access the generated log entry for the action.
Steps.Expected Result: Log entry is accessible.

Steps.Step Description: Verify that the log entry includes all required fields: user ID, timestamp, action type, affected data, outcome, and source IP (if applicable).
Steps.Expected Result: Log entry contains all mandatory SOX-compliant fields in the correct format.

test_cases.Preconditions: Log storage is accessible. SOX-relevant actions are enabled.
test_cases.Functionality: Log format and field completeness for SOX compliance
test_cases.Dataset: User credentials, sample action data
test_cases.Expected Result: All logs contain the required SOX-compliant fields in the correct format.

test_cases.Title: Simultaneous Update of the Same Record by Multiple Users

Steps.Step Description: User A logs into the system and opens Record X for editing.
Steps.Expected Result: User A successfully accesses Record X in edit mode.

Steps.Step Description: User B logs into the system and opens the same Record X for editing at the same time.
Steps.Expected Result: User B successfully accesses Record X in edit mode.

Steps.Step Description: User A modifies a field in Record X and saves the changes.
Steps.Expected Result: System saves User A's changes to Record X.

Steps.Step Description: User B modifies a different field in Record X and attempts to save the changes.
Steps.Expected Result: System detects concurrent modification and either merges changes, prompts User B about the conflict, or prevents the overwrite according to the concurrency management policy.

test_cases.Preconditions: Record X exists in the system. Both User A and User B have valid credentials and edit permissions.
test_cases.Functionality: Concurrency management during simultaneous record updates.
test_cases.Dataset: Record X, User A credentials, User B credentials.
test_cases.Expected Result: System maintains data consistency and prevents data loss or corruption when multiple users attempt to update the same record concurrently.

test_cases.Title: Simultaneous Creation of Records with Identical Unique Keys

Steps.Step Description: User A initiates the creation of a new record with unique key 'ABC123'.
Steps.Expected Result: User A is able to fill in the record creation form with key 'ABC123'.

Steps.Step Description: User B, at the same time, initiates the creation of a new record with the same unique key 'ABC123'.
Steps.Expected Result: User B is able to fill in the record creation form with key 'ABC123'.

Steps.Step Description: User A submits the form to create the record.
Steps.Expected Result: System creates the record with key 'ABC123' for User A.

Steps.Step Description: User B submits the form to create the record with the same key.
Steps.Expected Result: System detects the duplicate key and prevents User B from creating the record, displaying an appropriate error message.

test_cases.Preconditions: No record with key 'ABC123' exists. Both User A and User B have valid credentials and creation permissions.
test_cases.Functionality: Concurrency management during record creation with unique constraints.
test_cases.Dataset: User A credentials, User B credentials, unique key 'ABC123'.
test_cases.Expected Result: System enforces unique constraints and prevents duplicate records even under concurrent creation attempts.

test_cases.Title: Simultaneous Deletion and Update of the Same Record

Steps.Step Description: User A logs into the system and opens Record Y for editing.
Steps.Expected Result: User A successfully accesses Record Y in edit mode.

Steps.Step Description: User B logs into the system and opens the same Record Y for deletion.
Steps.Expected Result: User B successfully accesses Record Y in delete mode.

Steps.Step Description: User B deletes Record Y and confirms the deletion.
Steps.Expected Result: System deletes Record Y from the database.

Steps.Step Description: User A attempts to save changes to Record Y after it has been deleted by User B.
Steps.Expected Result: System notifies User A that Record Y no longer exists and prevents the update.

test_cases.Preconditions: Record Y exists in the system. Both User A and User B have valid credentials and appropriate permissions.
test_cases.Functionality: Concurrency management during simultaneous update and deletion of a record.
test_cases.Dataset: Record Y, User A credentials, User B credentials.
test_cases.Expected Result: System prevents updates to records that have been deleted concurrently, ensuring data consistency.

test_cases.Title: Read Consistency During Concurrent Updates

Steps.Step Description: User A logs into the system and opens Record Z for editing.
Steps.Expected Result: User A successfully accesses Record Z in edit mode.

Steps.Step Description: User B logs into the system and opens the same Record Z for editing.
Steps.Expected Result: User B successfully accesses Record Z in edit mode.

Steps.Step Description: User A updates a field in Record Z and saves the changes.
Steps.Expected Result: System saves User A's changes to Record Z.

Steps.Step Description: User B, without refreshing, attempts to read the value of the updated field in Record Z.
Steps.Expected Result: User B sees the value of the field as it was before User A's update (depending on isolation level), or is notified that the record has changed.

Steps.Step Description: User B refreshes the record view.
Steps.Expected Result: User B sees the updated value as saved by User A.

test_cases.Preconditions: Record Z exists in the system. Both User A and User B have valid credentials and edit permissions.
test_cases.Functionality: Read consistency and isolation during concurrent updates.
test_cases.Dataset: Record Z, User A credentials, User B credentials.
test_cases.Expected Result: System ensures read consistency and proper isolation during concurrent updates, according to the defined isolation level.

test_cases.Title: Verify language selection and persistence in Settings

Steps.Step Description: Launch the application and navigate to the Settings screen.
Steps.Expected Result: Settings screen is displayed with language options visible.

Steps.Step Description: Select a different language (e.g., Italian) from the language preferences list.
Steps.Expected Result: The application interface updates to display all text in the selected language.

Steps.Step Description: Close and relaunch the application.
Steps.Expected Result: The application interface remains in the previously selected language (Italian).

test_cases.Dataset: User account with default language set to English.
test_cases.Expected Result: User can select a language, and the application interface updates and persists the selection after restart.

test_cases.Title: Verify font size adjustment in display preferences

Steps.Step Description: Increase the font size to the maximum available setting.
Steps.Expected Result: All application text increases in size accordingly.

Steps.Step Description: Decrease the font size to the minimum available setting.
Steps.Expected Result: All application text decreases in size accordingly.

test_cases.Preconditions: User is logged in and on the Settings screen.

test_cases.Expected Result: User can adjust font size, and the change is reflected throughout the application interface.

test_cases.Title: Verify light/dark theme toggle in display preferences

Steps.Step Description: Navigate to the Settings screen and locate the display preferences section.
Steps.Expected Result: Display preferences section is visible with theme toggle options.

Steps.Step Description: Switch from light theme to dark theme.
Steps.Expected Result: Application interface updates to dark theme immediately.

Steps.Step Description: Switch back from dark theme to light theme.
Steps.Expected Result: Application interface updates to light theme immediately.

test_cases.Preconditions: User is logged in and on the Settings screen.
test_cases.Dataset: User account with default theme setting (light).
test_cases.Expected Result: User can toggle between light and dark themes, and the interface updates accordingly.

test_cases.Title: Verify error handling for unsupported language selection

Steps.Step Description: Navigate to the Settings screen and attempt to select a language not supported by the application (if possible).
Steps.Expected Result: Application displays an error message or prevents selection of unsupported language.

test_cases.Preconditions: User is logged in and on the Settings screen. Application has a defined set of supported languages.
test_cases.Dataset: User account; attempt to select unsupported language (e.g., German if not available).
test_cases.Expected Result: Application prevents selection of unsupported languages and provides appropriate feedback.
test_cases.Partial Coverage Description: Covers only negative scenario for language selection.

test_cases.Title: Verify persistence of display preferences after application restart

Steps.Step Description: Navigate to the Settings screen and change display preferences (e.g., set font size to large and theme to dark).
Steps.Expected Result: Display preferences are updated immediately in the application interface.

Steps.Step Description: Close and relaunch the application.
Steps.Expected Result: Display preferences (font size and theme) remain as previously set.

test_cases.Preconditions: User is logged in and on the Settings screen.
test_cases.Dataset: User account with default display preferences.
test_cases.Expected Result: Display preferences are retained after application restart.

test_cases.Title: Verify successful connection to Arxivar service for document listing

Steps.Step Description: Ensure the system is configured with valid Arxivar service credentials and endpoint.
Steps.Expected Result: System is ready to connect to Arxivar.

Steps.Step Description: Initiate the document acquisition process for a specific PoS.
Steps.Expected Result: System attempts to connect to Arxivar service.

Steps.Step Description: Monitor the connection process.
Steps.Expected Result: System successfully establishes a connection with Arxivar service.

test_cases.Preconditions: System has network access and valid Arxivar credentials configured. Arxivar service is operational.
test_cases.Functionality: Arxivar service connection and document listing initiation
test_cases.Dataset: Valid PoS identifier, valid Arxivar credentials
test_cases.Expected Result: System successfully connects to Arxivar and is ready to retrieve documents for the specified PoS.

test_cases.Title: Verify document listing based on type and status criteria

Steps.Step Description: Connect to Arxivar service as per standard procedure.
Steps.Expected Result: Connection to Arxivar is established.

Steps.Step Description: Request document list for a specific PoS with criteria: type='Invoice', status='Approved'.
Steps.Expected Result: System sends request with correct criteria to Arxivar.

Steps.Step Description: Receive and display the list of documents from Arxivar.
Steps.Expected Result: Only documents of type 'Invoice' and status 'Approved' for the specified PoS are listed.

test_cases.Preconditions: System is connected to Arxivar. At least one document of type 'Invoice' and status 'Approved' exists for the PoS.
test_cases.Functionality: Document filtering by type and status
test_cases.Dataset: PoS with known documents of various types and statuses
test_cases.Expected Result: System lists only documents matching the specified type and status for the PoS.

test_cases.Title: Verify system behavior when no documents match the criteria

Steps.Step Description: Connect to Arxivar service as per standard procedure.
Steps.Expected Result: Connection to Arxivar is established.

Steps.Step Description: Request document list for a specific PoS with criteria that do not match any documents (e.g., type='Contract', status='Pending').
Steps.Expected Result: System sends request with non-matching criteria to Arxivar.

Steps.Step Description: Observe the system's response to the empty result set.
Steps.Expected Result: System displays a message indicating no documents are available for the specified criteria.

test_cases.Preconditions: System is connected to Arxivar. No documents exist for the PoS with the specified criteria.
test_cases.Dataset: PoS with no documents matching the test criteria
test_cases.Expected Result: System gracefully handles empty results and informs the user that no documents are available.

test_cases.Title: Verify error handling when Arxivar service is unavailable

Steps.Step Description: Attempt to initiate document acquisition for a specific PoS.
Steps.Expected Result: System attempts to connect to Arxivar and fails.

Steps.Step Description: Observe the error message or handling mechanism.
Steps.Expected Result: System displays an appropriate error message indicating the service is unavailable.

test_cases.Preconditions: Arxivar service is intentionally made unavailable (e.g., network disconnected, service stopped).
test_cases.Functionality: Error handling for external service unavailability
test_cases.Dataset: PoS identifier, simulated Arxivar downtime
test_cases.Expected Result: System provides a clear error message and does not crash or hang when Arxivar is unavailable.

test_cases.Title: Verify system behavior with invalid PoS identifier

Steps.Step Description: Connect to Arxivar service as per standard procedure.
Steps.Expected Result: Connection to Arxivar is established.

Steps.Step Description: Request document list using an invalid or non-existent PoS identifier.
Steps.Expected Result: System sends request with invalid PoS to Arxivar.

Steps.Step Description: Observe the system's response to the invalid PoS identifier.
Steps.Expected Result: System displays an error message indicating the PoS is invalid or not found.

test_cases.Preconditions: System is connected to Arxivar. The PoS identifier used does not exist in Arxivar.
test_cases.Dataset: Invalid PoS identifier
test_cases.Expected Result: System gracefully handles invalid PoS input and informs the user appropriately.

test_cases.Title: Verify Successful Initial Data Load from Source System

Steps.Step Description: Monitor the data load process until completion.
Steps.Expected Result: Data load process completes successfully without interruption.

Steps.Step Description: Validate that all expected records from the source system are present in the target system.
Steps.Expected Result: All source records are accurately loaded into the target system.

test_cases.Preconditions: Target system is empty. Source system contains valid data. Migration tool/script is configured.
test_cases.Dataset: Source system dataset with known record count and structure.
test_cases.Expected Result: All data from the source system is successfully loaded into the target system with no loss or corruption.

test_cases.Title: Verify Data Integrity After Migration

Steps.Step Description: Complete the initial data migration from the source to the target system.
Steps.Expected Result: Data migration completes without errors.

Steps.Step Description: Select a representative sample of records from the source system.
Steps.Expected Result: Sample records are identified.

Steps.Step Description: Compare the sample records in the source and target systems for field-by-field accuracy.
Steps.Expected Result: All fields in the sample records match exactly between source and target.

test_cases.Preconditions: Initial data migration has been completed successfully.
test_cases.Dataset: Sample records from source system with expected values.
test_cases.Expected Result: Data in the target system matches the source system exactly for all migrated records.

test_cases.Title: Verify Handling of Invalid Data During Migration

Steps.Step Description: Prepare the source system with records containing invalid or corrupt data (e.g., missing required fields, invalid formats).
Steps.Expected Result: Source system contains records with known invalid data.

Steps.Step Description: Initiate the data migration process.
Steps.Expected Result: Data migration process starts.

Steps.Step Description: Monitor the migration process for error handling and logging.
Steps.Expected Result: Migration process identifies and logs invalid records without halting the entire migration.

Steps.Step Description: Verify that only valid records are migrated to the target system.
Steps.Expected Result: Invalid records are excluded from the target system; valid records are migrated.

test_cases.Preconditions: Migration tool supports error handling and logging. Source system contains both valid and invalid records.
test_cases.Dataset: Source dataset with a mix of valid and invalid records.
test_cases.Expected Result: Invalid records are not migrated; errors are logged; valid records are migrated successfully.

test_cases.Title: Verify Migration Performance for Large Data Volumes

Steps.Step Description: Prepare the source system with a large dataset (e.g., millions of records).
Steps.Expected Result: Source system contains a large volume of data.

Steps.Step Description: Initiate the data migration process and start a timer.
Steps.Expected Result: Migration process begins and timer is running.

Steps.Step Description: Monitor system resources and migration progress.
Steps.Expected Result: System resources are utilized efficiently; migration progresses without bottlenecks.

Steps.Step Description: Record the total time taken for migration and compare with performance benchmarks.
Steps.Expected Result: Migration completes within acceptable performance thresholds.

test_cases.Preconditions: Performance benchmarks are defined. Source system contains a large dataset.
test_cases.Dataset: Large source dataset (e.g., 1 million+ records).
test_cases.Expected Result: Migration completes within the defined performance criteria without failures.

test_cases.Title: Verify System Behavior on Migration Interruption and Resume

Steps.Step Description: Start the data migration process from the source to the target system.
Steps.Expected Result: Migration process starts successfully.

Steps.Step Description: Simulate an interruption (e.g., network failure, system crash) during migration.
Steps.Expected Result: Migration process is interrupted unexpectedly.

Steps.Step Description: Restore the system and resume the migration process.
Steps.Expected Result: Migration process resumes from the point of interruption or restarts as per design.

Steps.Step Description: Verify that no data is duplicated or lost after migration completes.
Steps.Expected Result: All records are present in the target system with no duplication or loss.

test_cases.Preconditions: Migration tool supports resume functionality. Mechanism to simulate interruption is available.
test_cases.Dataset: Source dataset with known record count.
test_cases.Expected Result: Migration resumes correctly after interruption, with no data loss or duplication.

test_cases.Title: Upload Excel File as Temporary Data Integration Solution

test_cases.Title: Mandatory Acquisition Date Recording for Each Data Upload

test_cases.Title: Reject Data Upload Without Acquisition Date

Steps.Step Description: Sort or filter the data records by acquisition date.

test_cases.Dataset: Multiple data records with varying acquisition dates, user credentials with viewing permissions.
test_cases.Expected Result: System allows users to trace and verify data freshness using the acquisition date for each record.

test_cases.Title: Handle Direct Integration When Available (Bypass Temporary Solution)

Steps.Step Description: Verify that the option to upload Excel files is disabled or hidden when direct integration is active.

test_cases.Title: Initial Import of PoS Master Data from MDM to ZENIT

Steps.Step Description: Ensure MDM contains at least one PoS record with all required fields populated.
Steps.Expected Result: MDM has valid PoS data ready for export.

Steps.Step Description: Trigger the initial import process in ZENIT to acquire PoS master data from MDM via ESB.
Steps.Expected Result: ZENIT initiates data acquisition from MDM.

Steps.Step Description: Wait for the import process to complete.
Steps.Expected Result: Import process completes without errors.

Steps.Step Description: Access the ZENIT Dashboard - Single PoS - PoS Master Data tab for the imported PoS.
Steps.Expected Result: All required PoS fields are displayed and populated as per the data in MDM.

test_cases.Preconditions: MDM contains at least one valid PoS record with all required fields populated. ZENIT is configured to connect to MDM via ESB.
test_cases.Functionality: Initial PoS data import from MDM to ZENIT
test_cases.Dataset: Sample PoS record in MDM with all fields populated.
test_cases.Expected Result: ZENIT successfully imports all PoS master data fields from MDM and displays them correctly in the Dashboard.

test_cases.Title: Near Real-Time Synchronization on PoS Insert/Update in MDM

Steps.Step Description: Ensure ZENIT and MDM are aligned after initial import.
Steps.Expected Result: ZENIT and MDM contain the same PoS records.

Steps.Step Description: Insert a new PoS record in MDM with all required fields populated.
Steps.Expected Result: New PoS record is present in MDM.

Steps.Step Description: Wait for near real-time integration to synchronize data to ZENIT.
Steps.Expected Result: ZENIT receives and processes the new PoS record.

Steps.Step Description: Access the ZENIT Dashboard - Single PoS for the new PoS.
Steps.Expected Result: The new PoS record is visible with all fields matching MDM.

Steps.Step Description: Update an existing PoS record in MDM (e.g., change Denomination or Address).
Steps.Expected Result: PoS record is updated in MDM.

Steps.Step Description: Wait for near real-time integration to synchronize the update to ZENIT.
Steps.Expected Result: ZENIT receives and processes the update.

Steps.Step Description: Access the ZENIT Dashboard - Single PoS for the updated PoS.
Steps.Expected Result: The updated field(s) reflect the changes made in MDM.

test_cases.Preconditions: ZENIT and MDM are aligned. Integration is active. User has access to both systems.
test_cases.Functionality: Near real-time synchronization of PoS data between MDM and ZENIT
test_cases.Dataset: PoS records in MDM for insert and update scenarios.
test_cases.Expected Result: ZENIT reflects all PoS inserts and updates from MDM in near real-time, with all fields correctly synchronized.

test_cases.Title: Field-Level Data Integrity for PoS Master Data

Steps.Step Description: Insert a PoS record in MDM with unique, known values for each required field (e.g., IdRice, Zona Code, Denomination, etc.).
Steps.Expected Result: PoS record is present in MDM with all fields populated with test values.

Steps.Step Description: Trigger synchronization to ZENIT (either via initial import or update).
Steps.Expected Result: ZENIT receives the PoS record.

Steps.Step Description: Access the ZENIT Dashboard - Single PoS - PoS Master Data tab for the imported PoS.
Steps.Expected Result: All fields are displayed in ZENIT.

Steps.Step Description: Verify that each field in ZENIT matches the corresponding value in MDM.
Steps.Expected Result: All field values in ZENIT are identical to those in MDM.

test_cases.Preconditions: MDM and ZENIT are operational. Test PoS record with known values is available in MDM.
test_cases.Functionality: Field-level data integrity for PoS master data
test_cases.Dataset: PoS record in MDM with unique test values for all fields.
test_cases.Expected Result: All PoS master data fields are transferred from MDM to ZENIT without loss or modification.

test_cases.Title: Privacy Compliance: Exclusion of Personal Numbers from PoS Data

Steps.Step Description: Insert a PoS record in MDM with both PoS phone numbers and personal numbers (e.g., Holder Cell, Holder Cell 2) populated.
Steps.Expected Result: PoS record in MDM contains both PoS and personal phone numbers.

Steps.Step Description: Trigger synchronization to ZENIT.
Steps.Expected Result: ZENIT receives the PoS record.

Steps.Step Description: Access the ZENIT Dashboard - Single PoS - PoS Master Data tab for the imported PoS.
Steps.Expected Result: PoS phone numbers are displayed.

Steps.Step Description: Verify that only PoS phone numbers (Telefono, Telefono 2) are present and personal numbers (Holder Cell, Holder Cell 2) are not displayed or stored in ZENIT.
Steps.Expected Result: Only PoS phone numbers are present; personal numbers are excluded, ensuring privacy compliance.

test_cases.Functionality: Privacy compliance for phone number fields in PoS data
test_cases.Dataset: PoS record in MDM with both PoS and personal phone numbers populated.
test_cases.Expected Result: ZENIT integrates only PoS phone numbers and excludes personal numbers, in compliance with privacy requirements.

test_cases.Title: Dashboard Display of PoS Master Data

test_cases.Title: Verify Real-Time Acquisition of GEO Credit Lines Data for PoS

Steps.Step Description: Ensure the GEO system has updated credit line data for a specific PoS.
Steps.Expected Result: GEO system contains the latest credit line data for the selected PoS.

Steps.Step Description: Trigger or wait for ZENIT to perform data acquisition from GEO system.
Steps.Expected Result: ZENIT initiates data retrieval from GEO system.

Steps.Step Description: Access the ZENIT Dashboard and navigate to 'Dashboard - Single PoS - Credit Management' tab for the selected PoS.
Steps.Expected Result: Dashboard displays the credit line data for the selected PoS.

Steps.Step Description: Verify that the displayed data matches the latest data present in the GEO system for all required fields.
Steps.Expected Result: All credit line fields (Zona Code, RICE Number, Basic credit line, Credit line extension, Total credit line, Consumed Credit line, Percentage of credit consumed, Residual credit line) match GEO system values.

test_cases.Preconditions: GEO system contains up-to-date credit line data for at least one PoS. ZENIT is configured to connect to GEO system.
test_cases.Functionality: Real-time data acquisition and display of GEO credit lines for PoS.
test_cases.Dataset: PoS with known credit line data in GEO system.
test_cases.Expected Result: ZENIT Dashboard displays the most recent GEO credit line data for the selected PoS in near real-time.

test_cases.Title: Verify Calculation of Percentage of Credit Consumed and Residual Credit Line

Steps.Step Description: Set up a PoS in GEO system with known values for 'Fido Totale Week' and 'Consumato Week'. Example: Fido Totale Week = 1000, Consumato Week = 250.
Steps.Expected Result: GEO system contains the specified values for the PoS.

Steps.Step Description: Trigger ZENIT to acquire data from GEO system.
Steps.Expected Result: ZENIT retrieves the data for the PoS.

Steps.Step Description: Access the ZENIT Dashboard and navigate to 'Dashboard - Single PoS - Credit Management' tab for the PoS.
Steps.Expected Result: Dashboard displays the credit line data for the PoS.

Steps.Step Description: Verify that '% consumato Week' is correctly calculated as (Consumato Week / Fido Totale Week) * 100. Example: (250/1000)*100 = 25%.
Steps.Expected Result: '% consumato Week' displays 25%.

Steps.Step Description: Verify that 'Residuo Week' is correctly calculated as (Fido Totale Week - Consumato Week). Example: 1000 - 250 = 750.
Steps.Expected Result: 'Residuo Week' displays 750.

test_cases.Preconditions: PoS exists in GEO system with known credit line values. ZENIT is operational and connected to GEO.
test_cases.Functionality: Calculation and display of derived credit line fields.
test_cases.Dataset: PoS with Fido Totale Week = 1000, Consumato Week = 250.
test_cases.Expected Result: ZENIT correctly calculates and displays '% consumato Week' and 'Residuo Week' for the PoS.

test_cases.Title: Verify Handling of Zero Total Credit Line in Percentage Calculation

Steps.Step Description: Set up a PoS in GEO system with 'Fido Totale Week' = 0 and 'Consumato Week' = 0.
Steps.Expected Result: GEO system contains the specified values for the PoS.

Steps.Step Description: Trigger ZENIT to acquire data from GEO system.
Steps.Expected Result: ZENIT retrieves the data for the PoS.

Steps.Step Description: Access the ZENIT Dashboard and navigate to 'Dashboard - Single PoS - Credit Management' tab for the PoS.
Steps.Expected Result: Dashboard displays the credit line data for the PoS.

Steps.Step Description: Verify that '% consumato Week' is handled gracefully (e.g., displays 0% or 'N/A', no division by zero error).
Steps.Expected Result: '% consumato Week' displays 0% or 'N/A', and no error is shown.

test_cases.Preconditions: PoS exists in GEO system with Fido Totale Week = 0. ZENIT is operational and connected to GEO.
test_cases.Functionality: Error handling in percentage calculation for zero total credit line.
test_cases.Dataset: PoS with Fido Totale Week = 0, Consumato Week = 0.
test_cases.Expected Result: ZENIT handles division by zero in '% consumato Week' calculation without error.

test_cases.Title: Verify Data Refresh Frequency is Near Real-Time

Steps.Step Description: Update credit line data for a PoS in the GEO system (e.g., change Consumato Week value).

Steps.Step Description: Monitor the ZENIT Dashboard 'Dashboard - Single PoS - Credit Management' tab for the PoS.

Steps.Step Description: Measure the time taken for the updated value to appear in the ZENIT Dashboard.
